title: 113_hr3349
content: The "Innovation Protection Act" is the short title of the Act. It addresses funding for the Patent and Trademark Office. The definitions in this section include the Director, Fund, Office, and Trademark Act of 1946. The Act addresses funding for the Patent and Trademark Office. The Lanham Act is amended to change funding for the United States Patent and Trademark Office. Fees collected will be available to the office. The Lanham Act is amended to establish the "United States Patent and Trademark Office Public Enterprise Fund" as a revolving fund in the Treasury. The fund allows the Director to use collected amounts without fiscal year limitation. The amendments made by the Act will take effect on the first day of the first fiscal year after enactment. The "United States Patent and Trademark Office Public Enterprise Fund" allows the Director to use collected fees without fiscal year limitation. Fees collected under title 35 and the Trademark Act of 1946 are deposited into the Fund. Unobligated balances from the Patent and Trademark Office Appropriation Account are also deposited into the Fund. The Patent and Trademark Fee Reserve Fund, established under section 42(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code, will be terminated upon the payment of all obligated amounts. Amounts deposited into the Fund will cover expenses, including administrative and operating expenses, without fiscal year limitation. The Director incurs expenses for the operation of services related to patents and trademarks as described in title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946. All expenses related to Office obligations are covered. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress summarizing the Office's operations, including financial details and staff levels by major activity. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the Office's financial plans, progress towards modernization, and audit results. Additionally, the Director must notify the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations of the Office's spending plan within 30 days of each fiscal year. The Director must provide an annual report to Congress on the Office's financial plans, modernization progress, and audit results. Each plan must summarize the Office's operations for the current fiscal year and detail its operating plan, including expense and staff needs. An independent audit of the Office's financial statements must be conducted annually. The Fund is required to submit a business-type budget to the President each year.
